MCQ 1 Question for Myosin and Actin
whyenzyme1
object_data.value:
One might ask: How does Troponin bind to Actin and Tropomyosin?
Quick answer is that Troponin is a complex that has 3-parts:
1. The one that binds to Calcium ions which we call Troponin - C. (We will know why we need this later)
2. The one that connects to Actin which we call Troponin - I
3. And the one that connects to Tropomyosin, which we call Troponin - T

You can click here to check out the links and play a subvideo that talks about it

object_data.name: whyenzyme1
object_data.value:
Links:
Overview: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troponin
Troponin-C: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troponin_C
Troponin-I: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troponin_I
Troponin-T: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troponin_T

object_data.name: Question Content for Myosin and Actin
MCQ 1 Question for Myosin and Actin
object_data.value: What is the thing that directly blocks the Myosin from crawling Actin?

object_data.name: MCQ 1 Question for Myosin and Actin
object_data.value:
This is right! Myosin is being blocked by the Tropomyosin.
Tropomyosin blocks the Myosin binding-sites in the Actin so that Myosin will not bind with the Actin.
Here's a video that will tell you how it works...

object_data.name: MCQ 1 Question for Myosin and Actin
object_data.value: You can replay the part what's blocking the Myosin from binding with the Actin...

object_data.name: Question Content for Myosin and Actin

value.text: High Calcium -> Tropomyosin is free to move
Low Calcium -> Myosin is free to move

object_data.name: MCQ 1 Question for Myosin and Actin
object_data.value: Pick the statement that is true

object_data.name: MCQ 1 Question for Myosin and Actin
object_data.value: Cool! Low Calcium ions would result to Troponin moving back the Tropomyosin to its blocking position. Thus, the amount of calcium ions determine the contraction and relaxation of the muscle. As show in the video on the right...

object_data.name: MCQ 1 Question for Myosin and Actin
object_data.value:
Let's review! Calcium ions bind to Troponin to move a protein away. If that protein moves away, then some protein is free to bind with another protein, making it free to do a power stroke...
You can repeat the part of the video to learn more...
